title: Development of a New Environmental In Situ TEM holder for Liquid Cell Research with Combined Electrochemical and Thermal Stimuli Control
content: In situ (scanning) transmission electron microscopy ((S)TEM) experiments in liquid phase are gaining momentum due to the development of sandwiched MEMS-based samples carriers â€“ liquid Nano-Cells. Various stimuli such as heating or biasing in liquid environments have been employed to study materials nucleation and growth [1], ion batteries [2], electrocatalysts [3], and more. The majority of commercial in situ (S)TEM sample holders utilize only four electrical contacts, limiting the combination of stimuli that users can simultaneously apply. However, to mimic real-world operational conditions in applications like proton exchange membranes, Zn-ion batteries, etc., requires the simultaneous combination of thermal and electrical stimuli, thus demanding a higher number of electrical signals.
